title: God's Majesty and Judgment
shortSummary: Psalm 76 celebrates God's powerful presence in Judah and His sovereign judgment over the nations. It highlights God's protection of His people, His fearful majesty, and calls for reverence and worship from all who know Him. This psalm encourages believers to trust in God's righteous power and respond with obedience and praise.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, attributed to Asaph

keyCharacters.name: Asaph
keyCharacters.description: The psalmist and chief musician who composed this psalm, known for his role in temple worship and inspired songs.

keyCharacters.name: God of Jacob
keyCharacters.description: The sovereign God who dwells in Zion, known for His mighty acts of judgment and protection of His people.

outline.heading: God’s Known Presence in Judah
outline.description: The psalm opens by declaring God’s fame and dwelling in Judah, specifically in Salem (Jerusalem) and Zion, emphasizing His established presence among His people.

outline.heading: God’s Power in Battle
outline.description: God’s mighty acts in defeating enemies are described, including breaking weapons and causing the chariot and horse to fall asleep, demonstrating His supreme power over human conflict.

outline.heading: The Fear of God’s Judgment
outline.description: The psalmist highlights the awe and fear inspired by God’s righteous judgment, which causes the earth to be still and saves the meek, underscoring God’s justice and mercy.

outline.heading: Call to Worship and Reverence
outline.description: The psalm concludes with an exhortation to vow and bring offerings to God, recognizing His power to humble princes and kings, and affirming His fearful majesty.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign power to protect and deliver you in times of trouble, knowing He controls all battles.
Approach God with reverence and awe, recognizing His righteous judgment and holy presence in your life.
Offer vows and worship to God regularly as an expression of gratitude and acknowledgment of His greatness.
Remember that God’s justice ultimately prevails over human pride and power, encouraging humility and obedience.

keyVerses.text: There brake he the arrows of the bow, the shield, and the sword, and the battle. Selah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully illustrates God’s ability to neutralize the weapons of His enemies, showing His supreme protection over His people.

keyVerses.text: Thou, even thou, art to be feared: and who may stand in thy sight when once thou art angry?
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the fearful reverence due to God because of His righteous anger and power, reminding believers of His holiness.

keyVerses.text: Surely the wrath of man shall praise thee: the remainder of wrath shalt thou restrain.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches that God can use even human wrath to accomplish His purposes while restraining excess, highlighting His sovereign control over all circumstances.

keyVerses.text: He shall cut off the spirit of princes: he is terrible to the kings of the earth.
keyVerses.significance: It declares God’s authority over earthly rulers, affirming that no power can stand against His will.
